ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course gave me language about genre and theory that have helped me better articulate and understand my own interests for future research. The syllabus was excellent and we covered a broad range of ways of writing about the self, which have interested me more in varieties of lyric essay that can blend genres together. I was introduced to theorists that write about what I'm interested in, and the theoretical readings paired well with the "literary" texts we read.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: readings, small size that allowed for fruitful discussion (this class worked really well as a seminar, I think it would be harder in a lecture format), pairing of theory with literature

Weaknesses: discussions sometimes took a little while to get going. If clearer prompts, questions, or focus points were offered at the beginning of class or even in the week prior while reading the texts, I think we could have had even better discussions.

The flexibility on assignment deadlines was nice, but I do think that firmer deadlines would have been helpful. I ended up saving everything until the end of the semester and think I would have engaged more deeply with the texts if I was forced to write a little earlier on.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely! Fascinating readings and thought-provoking discussions based on those readings.

Absolutely! Dr. Brass structured the class in a way that allowed for student creativity, without the class disintegrating into chaos. The readings were excellent: diverse enough to have challenging discussions regarding their connections and differences, but always clearly related to the overall theme of the class.  There was space for multiple identities in this class, which I really appreciated. Careful nuances were always observed when discussing the lived experiences of others and what the limits and possibilities of understanding those experiences are.
